hotspots.label: Tree Rings
hotspots.fact: Each dark and light ring in a tree trunk shows one year of growth! Scientists can count these rings to figure out exactly how old a tree is and learn about weather from the past. This is called **tree ring dating** — when scientists count the rings to tell how old something is and what the climate was like long ago.

vocabulary.definition: Circular patterns in wood that form as a tree grows, with each ring representing one year of the tree's life.

hotspots.label: Wood Structure
hotspots.fact: Trees are living things that grow from the inside out, adding new layers of wood each year to become stronger and taller! The lighter wood on the outside is newer growth, while the darker wood in the center is older. This is called **growth** — when living things get bigger and develop over time.

vocabulary.definition: When a living thing gets bigger and develops new parts, like how a tree adds new rings of wood every year.

hotspots.label: Different Log Sizes
hotspots.fact: Trees grow at different speeds depending on weather and soil conditions, which is why these logs are different sizes! A log that grew quickly in good weather might be wider than one that grew slowly during dry years. Scientists study how **environment** — all the things around a living thing like rain, sunshine, and soil — affects how living things grow.

vocabulary.definition: Everything around a living thing, including weather, soil, water, and sunlight, that affects how it lives and grows.

hotspots.label: Bark Layer
hotspots.fact: The dark outer layer protecting each log is called bark, and it protected the living tree from weather, insects, and damage! Bark is like a tree's skin that keeps it safe and healthy. This is called **adaptation** — special features that help a living thing survive in its environment.

vocabulary.definition: A special feature or skill that helps a living thing survive and thrive in its environment.
